All improvements including signal timing revisions, pavement marking upgrades, pavement
resurfacing, the addition of a northbound through lane on Brainard Road from NB ramps to Edenhall
Drive are estimated as part of the total construction cost. The CRFs associated with these secondary
improvements were not used to calculate the potential rate of return.

Rate of return calculations were not performed for the long term countermeasures.


RAMP CLEAR PROGRAM

ODOT's Ramp Clear program was created to reduce congestion on interchange ramps that experience
bottleneck and where traffic frequently backs up onto the freeway. The safety improvements to be
eligible under this program are expected to be low cost, with minimum or no right of way acquisition
and utilities, constructible in one construction season and capable of design build development.
Detailed description of the eligibility criteria and potential countermeasures to be considered for
Ramp Clear Program are included in Appendix J.

The IR-271/Cedar Road/Brainard Road interchange experiences daily congestion resulting in queue
spillback onto the mainline. Some of the countermeasures recommended in this safety study are
eligible for ODOT's Ramp Clear Program. The countermeasures used to calculate a rate of return in
Tables 4-7 were repackaged to be consistent with the Ramp Clear program. The following
combination of improvements is recommended for the Ramp Clear Program.

    >    Widen northbound IR-271 exit ramp between Cedar Rd bridge and Brainard Road
    >    Lane channelization improvements to southbound approach at Brainard Road and NB IR-271
         ramp intersection.
    >    Add an additional northbound through lane on Brainard from IR-271 north ramps to Edenhall
         Drive.
    >    Reconstruct Cedar/Brainard Road intersection and associated signal work to accommodate
         dual SB right and improve dual SB left turn movements.
The study area meets the eligibility criteria of recurring congestion and queue spillback onto the
freeway and above improvements can be constructed within the existing Right of way for less than
$2 million. Table 8 lists the total estimated project cost, crash reduction factors and resulting rate of
return for the countermeasures eligible for the Ramp Clear program.

Additional details on the Ramp Clear Program, detailed cost estimates and rate of return calculations
for the eligible improvements are included in Appendix J.

Improvements on Brainard Road between Cedar Road and northbound IR-271 ramps are excluded
from the Ramp Clear Program. Countermeasures within this segment of Brainard Road include the
following:
     >    Widening of northbound Brainard Road between Cedar Road and northbound IR-271 ramps.
          The lane configuration on the northbound approach of Brainard Road at the IR-271 ramp is
          T-TR-R
     >    Construction of a raised median to channelize right turning traffic destined to northbound IR-
          271 from through traffic on Brainard Road
     >    Right of way acquisition and utility relocation are anticipated with this improvement.
Table 9 lists the crash reduction factors, total estimated project costs and resulting rate of return for
the above countermeasures.

TABLE 9: RATE OF RETURN ­ BRAINARD RD -- CEDAR RD TO NB IR-271 RAMPS

                                                                     Rear-End/                     FHWA (Desktop Reference

                                                                     Sideswipe/All other          for Crash Reduction Factors)

11) Supplementary Notes
Federal funding for this project was provided by the Federal Highway Administration and administered by the Ohio
Department of Transportation.
12) Abstracts
This study report is for a Road Safety Audit conducted for the intersection of Cedar Road and Brainard Road in the City of
Lyndhurst. The purpose of the audit is to examine the existing conditions at this and nearby intersections, and suggest
short-term, low-cost safety improvement solutions.

   5858t                                                                                                              2
Executive Summary

The Road Safety Audit (RSA) for the intersection of Cedar Road and Brainard Road in the Cities of
Lyndhurst and Pepper Pike (see Figure 1) is one of several audits conducted by the Northeast Ohio
Areawide Coordinating Agency (NOACA) as part of NOACA's safety studies program for State Fiscal Year
(FY) 2012. The intersection was identified as a high-crash location based on NOACA's 2009 Crash Report
titled "Accident Characteristics & Intersection Accident Analysis". This intersection has a particularly
unusual circumstance in that it is located within the expanse of a vast, spread-out interchange which ramps
straddle Cedar Road and Brainard Road (see Figure 2). In addition to serving local traffic, it is also used as
a pass-through by regional traffic entering and exiting the I-271 Freeway in the area. Furthermore, the
pattern of traffic movements is greatly influenced by many local traffic generators and a peculiar set of
origin-destination characteristics.

 The purpose of this RSA is to have an independent road safety audit team (RSA Team) examine the
particulars of this intersection and other nearby roadway intersections with the I-271 Interchange ramps to
enable the RSA team to make suggestions for short term, low cost safety improvements, as well as
possible long term, higher cost improvements. The various intersections, referenced as Location 1,
Location 2, Location 3, and Location 4, are shown in Figure 2.

The RSA team, therefore, recommends the following low-cost, short-term; low-cost, medium-term; medium-
cost, longer term, and higher cost, long term improvements to increase the level of safety at this
intersection. The main recommendations, described separately for each location, are:


Location 1: Cedar Road/Brainard Road:
    Examine the timing and phasing of the traffic control signals with regards to the following modifications:
         o To provide a shorter cycle length.
         o To introduce a phasing sequence that provides a phase for exclusive, protected left-turn
             movements from the Brainard Road northbound approach.
    Provide more pronounced dashed lane-extension lines through the intersection to help moving traffic
    avoid encroaching on adjacent turn lanes, and to help drivers make better judgment regarding their
    travel paths.
    Improve the pavement sub-grade and surface conditions on all approaches of the intersection as well
    as within it to improve friction and to provide a better surface conducive to receiving lane marking paint
    for a longer lasting, more durable lane demarcation.
    Improve pavement markings where needed.
    Set back the stop bar for the exclusive left-turn lane on the Cedar Road westbound approach.
    Delete the pedestrian crosswalk for Cedar Road at its present location on the west side of the
    intersection and emphasize it at the east side of the intersection, as the heavy right-turn traffic
    movements inhibit pedestrians from attempting to cross the road at this location even during the recall
    pedestrian crossing phase.


5858t                                                                                                      4
    Convert the through lane on the Brainard Road southbound approach from an exclusive through lane
    to a shared through and right-turn lane.
      Consider incorporating information from the I-271--Cedar/Brainard Access Point Modification Study
    into this RSA report to develop a more comprehensive approach towards addressing the issues
    identified in this RSA study report.

Location 2: Brainard Road/I-271 Northbound Exit Ramp:
 Remove all obstructions to the line of site, especially the chain link fence on the bridge parapet, and
   nearby shrubberies that block the line of vision of vehicle drivers stopped at the traffic control signal of
   I-271 northbound exit ramp and looking to their left to check for oncoming southbound traffic on
   Brainard Road.
 Set back the stop bar for the exclusive left-turn bay on Brainard Road southbound approach.
 Improve pavement conditions, especially any crumbling or rutted pavements, to provide for better
   traction, smoother ride, and a pavement condition conducive to proper and longer lasting marking.
 Consider providing two right-turn bays on the I-271 northbound exit ramp at Brainard Road to increase
   the storage capacity and minimize traffic backups that often reach the freeway mainline.
 Consider building a marginal road beginning commencing at Brainard Road, on the opposite side of the
   I-271 northbound exit ramp, aligned with the exit ramp through lane, and relatively alongside the I-271
   northbound entrance ramp to Lander Road to help take traffic more directly to Landerbrook Drive and
   Lander Haven Drive. This marginal Road will carry or service traffic bound for Landerbrook Drive and
   Lander Haven Drive and will alleviate the traffic demand on the Cedar Road/Brainard Road intersection
   caused by the zigzag traffic movement pattern created by traffic exiting I-271 at the northbound exit
   ramp to Brainard Road and that then turns right to proceed to Cedar Road to turn left to reach Lander
   Road and then Landerbrook Drive and Lander Haven Drive (see diagram 2-1 in the Finding of Issues
   Section).
 Improve the pavement condition on Brainard Road.
 Restripe the stop line for the southbound approach and make it perpendicular to the curb of the
   roadway instead of the present slanted stop line.
 Add overhead lane use signs on the Brainard Road Bridge over I-271. The present sign is erected on
   the bridge parapet and cannot be seen by traffic coming from the I-271 southbound exit ramp.
 Remove the pedestrian crosswalk across Brainard Road. It is very unlikely pedestrians will cross to or
   from the southern side of the Brainard Road Bridge. That side of the bridge is not connected with or
   serviced by any sidewalks. Keep the pedestrian crosswalk across the I-271 northbound entrance ramp
   as pedestrians will more likely use it for the sidewalk on the northern side of the bridge is connected to
   sidewalks along Brainard Road.
 Re-examine the presently closed -by-hatching outer through lane on Brainard Road. This through lane
   may be reinstated if a tapered northbound receiving lane is built on Brainard Road. The tapered
   through lane may also serve traffic exiting at the I-271 southbound exit ramp and turns right from an
   exclusive right-turn bay proposed for the exit ramp as recommended for Location 4.




5858t                                                                                                       5
Location 3: Cedar Road/I-271 Southbound Entrance Ramp:
 Improve the curb near the bridge by setting it a little backward and increasing its curvature to permit
   vehicles in the inner left-turn bay on the Cedar Road eastbound approach to transition to the ramps
   easier and without encroaching on the adjacent left-turn lane extension line to minimize the potential for
   sideswipe passing crashes.
 Emphasize or Highlight the island and extension lines markings.
 Revisit alternative 10 presented in the I-271 Access Point Modification Study, completed in 2002, that
   provides for a free-flow entrance ramp to I-271 southbound at the Cedar Road eastbound approach,
   and a fourth approach created by a marginal road west of the freeway between Brainard and Cedar
   Road (see diagram below).
 Consider incorporating information from the I-271--Cedar/Brainard Access Point Modification Study into
   this RSA report to address issues identified in this RSA report.




5858t                                                                                                     6
        Alternative #10 in the I-271--Cedar/Brainard Access Point Modification Study prepared by
        Burgess & Niple in 2002 for ODOT District-12 under PID #21029




5858t                                                                                              7
Location 4: Brainard Road/I-271 Southbound Exit Ramp:
 Place overhead lane assignment signs on the bridge as the sign erected on the bridge parapet is not
   visible to traffic exiting at the I-271 southbound exit ramp and turning left to go south on Brainard.
 Re-examine the need for the "no-turn-on-red sign posted opposite the exit ramp.
 Add an exclusive right-turn bay on the exit ramp and convert the through and left lane to an exclusive
   left-turn lane only which will become a second left-turn lane.
 Build a long taper, through-lane on Brainard Road in the northbound direction to receive traffic from the
   outer through lane on the bride after opening it to traffic as it is currently closed by hatching.
 Place destination signs on the exit ramp to help drivers occupy the respective lane for the respective
   destination.




5858t                                                                                                  8
FIGURE A1: MARGINAL ROAD CONCEPT




Note: Auxiliary ramp that connects Brainard Rd and IR-271 NB exit ramp to Lander Road and/or Landerbrook Drive. This improvement was
recommended in the `Road Safety Audit (RSA) for the intersection of Cedar Rd/Brainard Rd and adjacent IR-271 Interchange Intersecttions' study
prepared by NOACA in June 2012.

Subject:              RE: D12 safety study growth rates



Hello Scott

Enclosed please find the growth rates based on the Regional Model inputs for the requested locations .
Please note that the rates are for the 2012 to 2035 projects. The model is not showing much of an
increase in some areas.
Let me know if you need additional information

From: SKnebel@LJBinc.com [mailto:SKnebel@LJBinc.com]
Sent: Wednesday, May 22, 2013 9:29 AM
To: Mahmoud Al-lozi
Cc: Brian.Blayney@dot.state.oh.us; BSliemers@LJBinc.com
Subject: D12 safety study growth rates

Mahmound

LJB is working with District 12 on several safety study locations. Attached is current traffic data for these
locations.

1. CUY-271-9.90/10.5 (Cedar Brainard interchange)
2. LAK-283-8.4/8.7 (Lake Shore at Reynolds Road)
3. LAK-615-4.45 (Center Street at Tyler Blvd)

Typically planning level growth rates are sufficient for use on a safety study. I know a couple of the study
locations are near interchanges that may have older certified traffic volumes.
I am interested in 20 year future volumes that is the easiest for NOACA to obtain whether as growth rates
applied to existing traffic data or applied to certified volumes of recent projects adjacent to the study
areas.

Does your schedule enable you to generate these numbers within the next 2 weeks?

Thank you for your help.

Scott



Scott Knebel, P.E.
Managing Principal
(937) 259-5067
(513) 532-8470 cell

    APPENDIX F
CLEARANCE INTERVAL
   CALCULATIONS
    CLEARANCE INTERVALS
The National Cooperative Highway Research Program (NCHRP) Report 731: Guidelines for Timing
Yellow and All-Red Intervals at Signalized Intersections was published July 2012. A number of
conclusions were reached as a result of the comprehensive study important to the safety performance
of signalized intersections.

    >   The Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Proposed Recommended Practice for the
        calculation of yellow change intervals and all-red clearance intervals is the methodology used
        by the highest percentage of state and local agencies.
    >   Drivers were documented to decelerate when turning at an intersection. The NCHRP Report
        731 recommended using a design speed of 20 mile per hour for the calculation of all red
        timing. Research conducted by the North Carolina Department of Transportation published
        by the ITE Journal determined that the average operating speed for left turning traffic is 17
        miles per hour.
    >   Using the current ITE guidelines to calculate the duration of yellow change and red clearance
        intervals has been shown to reduce total crashes between 8 and 14 percent while reducing
        injury crashes by approximately 12 percent.
    >   Using the current ITE guidelines to calculate the duration of yellow change and red clearance
        intervals has been shown to reduce red light running occurrences between 36 and 50 percent.
Vehicular clearance times were calculated for each study area intersection based on guidelines
published in the Ohio Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices and the ITE Proposed
Recommended Practice. The following posted speeds were used to calculate clearance intervals for
through phases:

    >   Cedar Road/Brainard Road: 35 MPH
    >   A 25 MPH speed was used to calculate clearance intervals for all leading left turn phases.
Calculated clearance intervals were included in the Synchro models for the proposed condition, as
described in the following section. A summary of the calculated clearance intervals for the three
signalized intersections is listed below in Table A and the calculations are appended at the end of this
section.




CLEARANCE INTERVALS                              1
TABLE A: PROPOSED CLEARANCE INTERVALS
                            YELLOW    ALL RED                FLASHING
  MOVEMENT        PHASE                              WALK
                            CHANGE   CLEARANCE              DON'T WALK
 BRAINARD @ NB I-271 RAMP
          NB      PH. 6        3.6      2.5          7.0       8.0
          SB      PH. 2        3.6      2.5          7.0       19.0
     SB LEFT      PH. 5        3.0      2.0          N/A       N/A
          EB      PH. 8        3.0      2.7          N/A       N/A
 BRAINARD @ SB I-271 EXIT RAMP
          NB      PH. 6        3.6      1.8          7.0       19.0
          SB      PH. 2        3.6      1.8          N/A       N/A
         WB       PH. 4        3.0      2.5          N/A       N/A
 BRAINARD @ CEDAR
          NB    PH. 6          3.6      2.1          N/A       N/A
    NB LEFT     PH. 1          3.0      2.5          N/A       N/A
          SB    PH. 2          3.6      2.1          7.0       29.0
     SB LEFT    PH. 5          3.0      3.0          N/A       N/A
          EB    PH. 4          3.6      2.5          N/A       N/A
     EB LEFT    PH. 7          3.0      3.0          N/A       N/A
         WB     PH. 8          3.6      2.5          7.0       29.0

                                                                       (East XWalk)                            (West Xwalk)                           (South Xwalk)                     (North Xwalk)
                   Curb to Curb or Edge Line to Edge Line
                   Distance (ft)                                           N/A                                      106                                    N/A                              105
                   Walking Rate (ft/sec)                                    3.5                                      3.5                                    3.5                              3.5

                   Ped Detector to Curb Distance (ft)
                   (6' if none)                                             10                                       10                                     10                               10
                   Walking Rate (ft/sec)                                    3.0                                      3.0                                    3.0                              3.0
                   Walk + Ped Clearance Time (sec)                       #VALUE!                                    38.7                                 #VALUE!                            38.3
                   Walk Interval (7 sec min)                                7.0                                      7.0                                    7.0                              7.0
                   Ped Clearance Time (sec) (Scenario 2)                 #VALUE!                                    31.7                                 #VALUE!                            31.3

                   between calculated pedestrian clearance scenarios.


                   YELLOW CLEAR. INTERVAL                                          Brainard Rd.                            Brainard Rd.                             Cedar Rd.                      Cedar Rd.
                                                                             Nb               Nb Lt                  Sb               Sb Lt                   Eb                Eb Lt       Wb              Wb Lt
                   Signal Design Speed (mph)                                 35                 25                   35                 25                    35                 25         35               25
                   Approximate Grade (%)                                      0                  0                    0                  0                     0                  0          0                0
                   Calculated Yellow Int.                                    3.6                2.8                  3.6                2.8                   3.6                2.8        3.6              2.8
                   Yellow Interval (sec)                                     3.6                3.0                  3.6                3.0                   3.6                3.0        3.6              3.0
                   Note: TCDH recommends yellow intervals lengths greater than 3 sec and no longer than 5 sec. OMUTCD recommends interval lengths between 3 - 6 sec.
                   This table will recommend yellow intervals as calculated by the ITE Proposed Recommended Practice (1985) except where calculated intervals exceed 5 sec
                   and extreme speed and grade conditions do not exist.


                   RED CLEARANCE INTERVAL                                        Brainard Rd.                              Brainard Rd.                             Cedar Rd.                      Cedar Rd.
                                                                             Nb             Nb Lt                    Sb               Sb Lt                  Eb                 Eb Lt       Wb              Wb Lt
                   Signal Design Speed (mph)                                  35              25                     35                 25                    35                  25         35               25
                   Width of Intersection (ft)                                110              90                     94                125                   115                 135        130              110
                   Length of Vehicle (ft)                                     0                0                      0                  0                    0                   0          0                0
                   Calculated Red Int.                                       2.1              2.5                    1.8                3.4                  2.2                 3.7        2.5              3.0
                   Red Interval (sec)                                        2.1              2.5                    1.8                3.0                  2.2                 3.0        2.5              3.0
                   Note: This table will recommend all-red intervals as calculated by the ITE Proposed Recommended Practice except where calculated intervals are greater
                   than 3 sec. Red Clearance Interval based on (w+L)/v equation where L=0 ft.

                   Ped Detector to Curb Distance (ft)

Q:\ODOT_OP\0106676A.00 - VAR-STW Safety Studies 2012\011 District 12\01_CUY-271-9.9_10.5\Dev\Tools\Clearance Intervals\F-130_Clearance Intervals 2012 MUTCD.xls                                            Revised 8/2010
   APPENDIX G
CAPACITY ANALYSIS
    REPORTS
      CAPACITY ANALYSIS
Intersections are graded using a level of service (LOS) designation expressed in terms of letter grades.
Level of service is a quality measure describing operational conditions with a traffic stream with LOS A
representing the highest quality traffic flow and minimal delay, and LOS F representing poor traffic
operations, significant delay, and substantial queuing. Level of service is defined in terms of vehicle
delay, as published in the Highway Capacity Manual (Transportation Research Board, 2010). Levels of
service thresholds for signalized intersections have been summarized in Table A.

TABLE A: LEVELS OF SERVICE THRESHOLDS FOR SIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS
                              CONTROL DELAY
LEVEL OF SERVICE
                              (SECONDS PER VEHICLE)
  A                            10
  B                           > 10 and  20
  C                           > 20 and  35
  D                           > 35 and  55
  E                           > 55 and  80
  F                           > 80

Traffic signal operation was evaluated for the four signalized intersections along Brainard Road and
Cedar Road with the Interstate 271 interchange ramps including the intersection of Brainard Road and
Cedar Road. This analysis assists in evaluating the level of benefit provided by the recommended safety
countermeasures aimed at reducing congestion. The following conditions were evaluated using design
year 2035 traffic volume projections. The results for the critical peak hours (AM and PM) are
summarized in Table B. Detailed reports are included at the end of this section.

2035 EXISTING CONDITIONS
Existing conditions were analyzed using TEC/DLZ traffic study Synchro models. The signal timings
recommended by TEC were used for the Brainard Road intersections and the following changes were
made to the existing condition models:
       > Minimal volume adjustments were made to balance counted traffic volumes between
         intersections along Brainard Road. Removed any growth factors for individual movements.
       > Lane utilization factors were calculated for dual-lane movements along the Brainard Road
         corridor using documented traffic volumes. Those movements include: westbound left turn at the
         Brainard/Southbound IR-271 Exit ramp, southbound through at Brainard/Northbound IR-271
         Exit ramp, southbound left turn at Cedar/Brainard, and eastbound left turn at Cedar/Brainard.
       > The intersection of southbound entrance ramp to IR-271 at Cedar Road was added to the models.
         Current traffic signal timings provided by the City of Beachwood were used in the existing
         condition analysis.
       > Lane utilization factors for the eastbound movements at the southbound IR-271 entrance ramp at
         Cedar Road were adjusted from default values to more accurately represent existing lane
         utilization as witnessed in the field.




CAPACITY ANALYSIS                               1
2035 PROPOSED COUNTERMEASURES
      > Proposed models analyzed the recommended capacity and lane assignment modifications as
        listed in the Countermeasures section of the report.
      > Proposed analysis retained TEC's recommended cycle lengths (AM Peak ­ 120 seconds, PM
        Peak -135 seconds) for the Brainard Road corridor and optimized splits and offsets.
      > The Cedar Road and IR-271 southbound entrance ramp intersection was analyzed with the
        existing cycle length (200 seconds) since it is part of a separate coordinated system; however,
        splits were optimized to minimize corridor congestion.
      > Proposed clearance intervals and pedestrian timings were used.
      > Dual-service left-turn (twice per cycle) was eliminated for the southbound left turn phase at the
        Cedar/Brainard intersection. All protected left-turn phases were analyzed as single-service
        leading phases.
      > Proposed storage lane lengths were used.
      > Lane utilization factors were updated to default values as the proposed countermeasures are
        designed to balance lane utilization.
The proposed condition shows improved levels-of service and decrease in vehicle delay for the majority
of movements for all study intersections. Intersections either maintained or improved Levels of service
by at least one letter grade for the peak time periods. However, several movements still show poor or
failing levels of service which can be attributed to high volume to capacity (v/c) ratios indicating
movements are near or over capacity.

2035 SPECIAL CONDITION
The special condition scenario analyzed the addition of a directional exit ramp from northbound
Interstate 271 to eastbound Cedar Road, creating an intersection west of Brainard Road. Traffic volumes
were collected for the peak hour time period using video data for those vehicles originating from the I-
271 northbound exit ramp destined to eastbound Cedar Road, this maneuver is completed under the
existing conditions by turning right (south) from the IR-271 NB exit at Brainard Rd and then left (east)
at the Cedar/Brainard intersection. These volumes were used to model the demand for the directional
eastbound exit ramp and also redistribute traffic volumes from southbound left turn to eastbound through
movement at the Cedar/Brainard intersection.
Detailed capacity reports are included at the end of this section.

CAPACITY ANALYSIS                                                      3
MEASURES OF EFFECTIVENESS
Measures of Effectiveness (MOE) are quantitative indicators to help compare intersection and network
operation performance. MOE indicators may include delays, stops, fuel consumption, queuing penalty,
dilemma vehicles and emissions. MOE information of 2035 operating conditions under the existing
and proposed geometric scenarios is summarized in Table C.

MOEs indicate that the proposed recommendations provide operational improvements compared to the
existing for the majority of indicators along the Brainard corridor. Most notably, total delay (hours)
and un-served vehicles show improvement at all intersections.

EMH, LJB Inc.                                                                                             Page 3
    APPENDIX H
STORAGE LANE LENGTH
   CALCULATIONS
        STORAGE LANE LENGTHS
Turn lane lengths were calculated for turn lanes for the study intersections along the Brainard Road
corridor and Cedar Rd/IR-271 SB ramps intersection. Lane lengths were first calculated using
guidelines specified in the Location and Design Manual Section 401 (Ohio Department of
Transportation). Lane lengths based on the ODOT's standard criteria assume posted speed limits and
include vehicle storage and a 50 foot diverging taper. The calculated lengths were compared to the
95th percentile queue lengths generated by SimTraffic modeling software. A recommended length is
provided based on this comparison and available space between adjacent intersections. A summary of
the lane sizing comparison is shown in Table A with lane sizing calculations attached to this section.

Turn lane lengths were calculated using the following parameters:
                    >      2035 PM peak traffic volumes
                    >      Lengths rounded up in 5-foot increments

TABLE A: STORAGE LENGTH SUMMARY
                                                                           ODOT STORAGE        95TH PERCENTILE QUEUE
                                                                                                                            RECOMMENDED
 INTERSECTION MOVEMENT                     EXISTING                                 PM PEAK   AM PEAK        PM PEAK
                                                           AM PEAK HOUR                                                        LENGTH
                                                                                     HOUR      HOUR           HOUR
 BRAINARD @ CEDAR RD
 EB LEFT (DUAL)                               650'                    315'            470'    184' - 202'    280' - 290'      No change
 WB LEFT                                      140'                    110'            115'        50'           215'          No change
 WB RIGHT                                     420'                    170'            645'        50'           590'          No change
 NB LEFT                                      410'                    145'            185'        95'           170'          No change
 NB RIGHT                                     100'                    125'            185'    135' - 135'    260' - 170'        250' *
 SB LEFT (DUAL)                               350'                    590'            325'    281' - 315'    185' - 413'        375'
 SB RIGHT                                     350'                    660'            725'       266'           480'            365'

 BRAINARD @ NB I-271 RAMP
 EB LEFT                                      460'                    325'            425'       315'           304'          add lane
 EB LEFT-RIGHT                                  -                      -                  -      397'           350'          add lane
 EB RIGHT                                    THRU                     435'            375'         -             73'            250'
 NB RIGHT                                     440'                    385'            720'        23'            93'            400'
 SB LEFT                                      390'                    210'            215'       134'           348'            460'
 CEDAR @ SB ENTRANCE
 EB RIGHT (DUAL)                              265'                1355'               1085'   449' - 485'    454' - 521'      add lane
 WB LEFT (DUAL)                               640'                    630'            950'    688' - 629 '   974' - 1140'       900'
 * NB   right turn lane converted to shared through/right turn lane

                                                                                                                                    ADT Factor
Project Service Life                         20 years
Present ADT (PADT)                        39774 veh / day                                                      Average ADT =              (PADT + FADT)/2 = (             39774       +              42520.44     )=        41147.22
Future ADT (FADT)                         42520 veh / day                                                      ADT Factor =             Average ADT / PADT =             41147.22     /               39774       =           1.03

                                                                                                                              Average Annual Benefits
Annual PDO Benefits = Estimated PDO Crash Reduction * Avg PDO Cost                                                          Select Facility Type Below:              =              8.78        *          $            8,128.00 =         $             71,335.66

Annual INJ.-FAT. Benefits = Estimated INJ.-FAT. Crash Reduction * Avg INJ.-FAT. Cost                                   Cities and Incorporated Villages              =              4.95        *          $        74,246.00 =            $           367,859.23
Total Benefits                                                                                                                                                                                                                =            $           439,194.89

     APPENDIX J
RAMP CLEAR PROGRAM
  DOCUMENTATION
RampClearProgram
Overview:
ODOT's low-cost RampClear Program was created in the summer of 2012 to
reduce congestion on interchanges ramps where traffic frequently backs up onto
the freeway. These traffic queues are a serious safety concern as stopped vehicles
co-mingled with high-speed traffic can lead to catastrophic crashes that result in
serious injuries and deaths.

Eligibility:
To be considered for the program, ramp locations typically must:
    · Experience routine, documented queues onto the freeway
    · Be $2M or less to improve
    · Involve minimal or no right of way and utilities
    · Qualify for CE Level 1 environmental document
    · Be reconstructed in one construction season, and
    · Be capable of Design Build development
    · Special consideration will be given to commercial/retail areas

Potential countermeasures could include:
   · Restricting traffic movements (particularly at adjacent intersections)
   · Signal phasing, signal timing/coordination, queue flushing timing plans
   · Turn lane construction
   · Changes in lane use
   · Queue warning systems for the freeway mainline
   · Improving operations/capacity at adjacent intersections that affect ramp operations

Approval Process:
  · The District Safety Review Team will forward candidate locations to the Office Administrator of
      Roadway Engineering (RE).
  · Central Office RE and the Office of Traffic will review candidate locations to determine feasibility and
      cost.
  · RE will send qualified locations to ODOT's Highway Safety Program Manager for funding approval.
  · The Highway Safety PM will assign a consultant to work with the District and RE to develop a Design
      Build Scope. The consultant may be asked to perform other tasks as assigned.
  · The RE Administrator will have final approval over the design concept and design reviews.
  · The District Project Manager will retain responsibility and decision-making authority over the
      remaining elements of the Design Build project.

Note: Locations that are deemed ineligible for the RampClear Program may be eligible for safety funding
through the traditional review and approval process. District Offices can submit a safety analysis/study and
application to Central Office by the April 30 or September 30 deadlines. The Highway Safety PM may grant an
interim review if there is evidence a project can be constructed quickly outside the traditional review and
approval process.
